content:
In ModRMod_{R}ModR​, every module of the form (A1⊕...⊕An)⊗p(A_{1} \oplus ... \oplus A_{n})^{\otimes p}(A1​⊕...⊕An​)⊗p is a R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sp​]-bimodule by making:

  • Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ acting by permutation of the summands A1,...,AnA_{1},...,A_{n}A1​,...,An​ and
  • Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​ by permutation of the 1st1^{st}1st, ..., pthp^{th}pth factors A1⊗...⊗AnA_{1} \otimes ... \otimes A_{n}A1​⊗...⊗An​.

You can imagine that in terms of noncommutative homogeneous polynomials. If you have a non commutative homogeneous polynomial of degree ppp, P∈Rp⟨X1,...,Xn⟩P \in R_{p} \langle X_{1},...,X_{n}\rangleP∈Rp​⟨X1​,...,Xn​⟩, then Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ permutes X1,...,XnX_{1},...,X_{n}X1​,...,Xn​ whereas Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​ permutes the factors in every summand of the polynomial which are all of the form Xi1...XipX_{i_{1}}...X_{i_{p}}Xi1​​...Xip​​ for 1≤i1,...,ip≤n1 \le i_{1},...,i_{p} \le n1≤i1​,...,ip​≤n.

More generally, I guess that C[(A1⊕...⊕An)⊗p,(A1⊕...⊕An)⊗p]\mathcal{C}[(A_{1} \oplus ... \oplus A_{n})^{\otimes p},(A_{1} \oplus ... \oplus A_{n})^{\otimes p}]C[(A1​⊕...⊕An​)⊗p,(A1​⊕...⊕An​)⊗p] is a R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sp​]-bimodule in the same way in a symmetric bimonoidal RRR-linear category (C,⊗,⊕)(\mathcal{C},\otimes,\oplus)(C,⊗,⊕).

A R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-module is the same thing that a RRR-linear representation of Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​, in the same way a R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sp​]-bimodule is the same thing that a RRR-module which is at the same time a representation of Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ and a representation of Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​, in a compatible way. Is there a name for such a "module which is a linear representation of two symmetric groups in a compatible way", or more generally for a module which is a linear representation of two groups in a compatible way? If RRR is a field of characteristic 000, then Schur functors or Young diagrams classify irreducible representations of a symmetric group. What about the same facts for such double representations?

Well, I've thought a bit. If instead of a bimodule, you look at left-left-bimodule ie. with the two actions on the left which are compatible, then a R[Sn],R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}],R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sn​],R[Sp​]-left-left-bimodule is the same thing than a R[Sn]⊗R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}] \otimes R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sn​]⊗R[Sp​]-module which is the same that a R[Sn×Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n} \times \mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sn​×Sp​]-module. So what I'm thinking to are the linear representations of the groups of the form Sn×Sp\mathfrak{S}_{n} \times \mathfrak{S}_{p}Sn​×Sp​ I guess.
The compatibility of the two actions is reflected in the fact that (σ,id).(id,τ)=(id,τ).(σ,id)(\sigma,id).(id,\tau) = (id,\tau).(\sigma,id)(σ,id).(id,τ)=(id,τ).(σ,id).
And there is a question about these representations on MathOverflow

And the answer is the irreducible representations (on a field of characteristic 0) of Sn×Sp\mathfrak{S}_{n} \times \mathfrak{S}_{p}Sn​×Sp​ are the tensor product of an irreducible representation of Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ and an irreducible representation of Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​
So my problem is solved :sweat_smile:
Jean-Baptiste Vienney has marked this topic as resolved.

By the way:

And the answer is the irreducible representations (on a field of characteristic 0) of Sn×Sp\mathfrak{S}_{n} \times \mathfrak{S}_{p}Sn​×Sp​ are the tensor product of an irreducible representation of Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ and an irreducible representation of Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​

this last (well-known) result is a thing @Joe Moeller, @Todd Trimble and I needed in our paper on Schur functors. It follows from the fact that the rationals are a splitting field for all the symmetric groups.

By contrast, unless I'm getting mixed up, not every tensor product of two irreducible representations of Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 over the rationals gives an irreducible representation of Z/3×Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3 \times \mathbb{Z}/3Z/3×Z/3.

To see this, note that even though Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3 is abelian, over the rationals its regular representation splits into just two irreducible representations, one 2-dimensonal and one 1-dimensional (the trivial representation).
Then tensor that 2d rep with itself; the resulting 4d rep of Z/3×Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3 \times \mathbb{Z}/3Z/3×Z/3 is not irreducible!
None of this sort of nonsense happens with the symmetric groups.
Thanks, it's interesting. But I don't know what means "the rationals are a splitting field for all the symmetric group". I only know what is a splitting field of a polynomial.

It's explained in our paper Schur functors in the proof of Lemma 6.5 on page 41:

Lemma 6.5. Let k be a field of characteristic zero and let n1,...,npn_1, . . . , n_pn1​,...,np​ be a collection
of natural numbers. Then every irreducible representation of k[Sn1×⋯×Snp]k[S_{n_1} \times \cdots \times S_{n_p}]k[Sn1​​×⋯×Snp​​] is a tensor product ρ1⊗⋯⊗ρp\rho_1 \otimes \cdots \otimes \rho_pρ1​⊗⋯⊗ρp​ of irreducible representations ρi\rho_iρi​ of k[Sni]k[S_{n_i} ]k[Sni​​] that are determined uniquely up to isomorphism.
Briefly, kkk is a splitting field for a finite group GGG if each irreducible representation of GGG has kkk as its endomorphism algebra.
Ok, I'm going to read that.

With a polynomial over a field kkk, when you extend the field the polynomial can factor into more factors. But when this doesn't happen - when the polynomial over kkk doesn't get more factors as you extend the field - we say kkk is a splitting field for the polynomial.

With a representation of a group over a field kkk, when you extend the field the representation can break up into a sum of more irreducible representations. But when this never happens - when any representation over kkk doesn't break into more irreducible representations as you extend the field - we say kkk is a splitting field for the group.
We could also talk about the splitting field of a particular representation but I haven't seen people do that.
The concept of splitting field is very general, and it always means "the field is big enough that extending it further doesn't let you do more."
So, the algebraic closure of a field is always a splitting field for everything, but you usually don't need to extend that far to get a splitting field.
Jean-Baptiste Vienney has marked this topic as unresolved.

That's clear to me that if P∈k[X]P \in k[X]P∈k[X], if lll is an extension of kkk, then P∈l[X]P \in l[X]P∈l[X] and so you can look at new roots in lll. But that's not so clear to me how if you have a kkk-representation of GGG, it is going to become a lll-representation of GGG. If (ρ,V)(\rho,V)(ρ,V) is a kkk-representation of GGG, how do you make it a lll-representation of GGG?
Is it related to extension of scalars?
Not extension, I guess it uses coextension of scalars.
It's extension of scalars. Form V′=l⊗kVV' = l \otimes_k VV′=l⊗k​V and you get a representation (V′,ρ′)(V', \rho')(V′,ρ′) of GGG via ρ′(g)=1l⊗ρ(g)\rho'(g) = 1_l \otimes \rho(g)ρ′(g)=1l​⊗ρ(g).

In general almost anything you have defined over a field of kkk, like an associative algebra or a Lie algebra or an algebraic variety or a scheme, becomes the same sort of thing over any field extension of kkk, via extension of scalars.
Ok, thanks

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

In ModRMod_{R}ModR​, every module of the form (A1⊕...⊕An)⊗p(A_{1} \oplus ... \oplus A_{n})^{\otimes p}(A1​⊕...⊕An​)⊗p is a R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sp​]-bimodule by making:

  • Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ acting by permutation of the summands A1,...,AnA_{1},...,A_{n}A1​,...,An​ and
  • Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​ by permutation of the 1st1^{st}1st, ..., pthp^{th}pth factors A1⊗...⊗AnA_{1} \otimes ... \otimes A_{n}A1​⊗...⊗An​.

You can imagine that in terms of noncommutative homogeneous polynomials. If you have a non commutative homogeneous polynomial of degree ppp, P∈Rp⟨X1,...,Xn⟩P \in R_{p} \langle X_{1},...,X_{n}\rangleP∈Rp​⟨X1​,...,Xn​⟩, then Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ permutes X1,...,XnX_{1},...,X_{n}X1​,...,Xn​ whereas Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​ permutes the factors in every summand of the polynomial which are all of the form Xi1...XipX_{i_{1}}...X_{i_{p}}Xi1​​...Xip​​ for 1≤i1,...,ip≤n1 \le i_{1},...,i_{p} \le n1≤i1​,...,ip​≤n.

More generally, I guess that C[(A1⊕...⊕An)⊗p,(A1⊕...⊕An)⊗p]\mathcal{C}[(A_{1} \oplus ... \oplus A_{n})^{\otimes p},(A_{1} \oplus ... \oplus A_{n})^{\otimes p}]C[(A1​⊕...⊕An​)⊗p,(A1​⊕...⊕An​)⊗p] is a R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sp​]-bimodule in the same way in a symmetric bimonoidal RRR-linear category (C,⊗,⊕)(\mathcal{C},\otimes,\oplus)(C,⊗,⊕).

A R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-module is the same thing that a RRR-linear representation of Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​, in the same way a R[Sn]R[\mathfrak{S}_{n}]R[Sn​]-R[Sp]R[\mathfrak{S}_{p}]R[Sp​]-bimodule is the same thing that a RRR-module which is at the same time a representation of Sn\mathfrak{S}_{n}Sn​ and a representation of Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​, in a compatible way. Is there a name for such a "module which is a linear representation of two symmetric groups in a compatible way", or more generally for a module which is a linear representation of two groups in a compatible way? If RRR is a field of characteristic 000, then Schur functors or Young diagrams classify irreducible representations of a symmetric group. What about the same facts for such double representations?

Bonjour! A late comment on your general question above about two groups acting in a compatible way in the same vector space: you may have a look at Howe duality (easy to google, also as "dual reductive pairs"), named after my colleague Roger Howe at Yale, who was inspired by the case of a symplectic group, and an orthogonal group O(Q)O(Q)O(Q) associated to an even dimensional non-degenerate quadratic space (E,Q)(E, Q)(E,Q), acting in L2(E)L^2(E)L2(E). The orthogonal groups acts here in a natural way (Anglosaxons say "by a permutation representation") and the symplectic group acts via the so called Weil representation, which is not so "natural" (it comes actually from the oscillator representation in Quantum Mechanics, via the Stone-von Neumann theorem for the Heisenberg group). The two actions commute (this is what you mean, I guess, when you say that they are compatible). A baby example of this would be the case of the natural representation of O(Q) O(Q)O(Q) in L2(E)L^2(E)L2(E) for a rank 2 quadratic form QQQ. If you have a keen eye you can see a group of intertwining operators of this representation which behaves exactly like SL(2,K) SL(2,K)SL(2,K) (KKK denotes the base field, which could be a local or finite field!). The original Howe duality has unfolded in many ways and the question arises whether this is a case of a more general phenomenon, including the classical Schur-Weyl duality, quantum analogues, etc, which could be nicely expressed in categorical terms. I guess John may have some categorical insights on this...
PS For an (old) elementary account of this (no quantum mechanics in sight) you may have a look at http://www.numdam.org/item/10.24033/msmf.240.pdf (chapitre 1) or also JSA_PSPUM_Gelfand-Weil
http://JSA_PSPUM_Gelfand-Weil

Thanks, I didn't know about Howe duality. I'm interested by Schur-Weyl duality, in the original version you look at two actions which commute on (C⊕n)⊗p(\mathbb{C}^{\oplus n})^{\otimes p}(C⊕n)⊗p. First Sp\mathfrak{S}_pSp​ acts by permutation of the factors C⊕n\mathbb{C}^{\oplus n}C⊕n, secondly GL(n,C)GL(n,\mathbb{C})GL(n,C) acts simultaneously in the same way on the ppp factors, by g.(x1⊗...⊗xp)=(g.x1)⊗...⊗(g.xp)g.(x_{1}\otimes...\otimes x_{p}) = (g.x_{1})\otimes ... \otimes (g.x_{p})g.(x1​⊗...⊗xp​)=(g.x1​)⊗...⊗(g.xp​). Now you can look only at the action of Sn⊆GL(n,C)\mathfrak{S}_{n} \subseteq GL(n,\mathbb{C})Sn​⊆GL(n,C) and then you obtain exactly the two compatible actions of the symmetric group I was talking about. I don't know about Howe duality, but there is maybe a way to state different versions of Schur-Weyl duality in a same categorical way. Maybe could we start with something like: in a symmetric monoidal (to get ⊗\otimes⊗) C\mathbb{C}C-linear (to get C\mathbb{C}C) category with biproducts (to get ⊕\oplus⊕), Schur-Weyl duality states that ... .

So a question I'm interested about now is: can we generalize Schur-Weyl duality to symmetric monoidal C\mathbb{C}C-linear categories with biproducts such that the monoidal unit III generates the objects ie. every object is isomorphic to I⊕nI^{\oplus n}I⊕n for some n≥1n \ge 1n≥1 ?

Jorge Soto-Andrade said:

http://JSA_PSPUM_Gelfand-Weil

There is a problem with this link, doesn't work

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

So a question I'm interested about now is: can we generalize Schur-Weyl duality to symmetric monoidal C\mathbb{C}C-linear categories with biproducts such that the monoidal unit III generates the objects ie. every object is isomorphic to I⊕nI^{\oplus n}I⊕n for some n≥1n \ge 1n≥1 ?

It is not quite correct, because here you could have I=HI=\mathbb{H}I=H for instance.
How would you make the quaternions into the monoidal unit of C-linear symmetric monoidal category with biproducts?
VecHVec_{\mathbb{H}}VecH​?
And using C→H\mathbb{C} \rightarrow \mathbb{H}C→H for the C\mathbb{C}C-linear part
Since the quaternions aren't a field you'll need to say what you mean by Vec_H.
Ok, ModHMod_{\mathbb{H}}ModH​ so.
How are you tensoring modules of this noncommutative ring?
Ok, you can't, I didn't think to that.
In fact, that's nice, because I don't want I≅HI \cong \mathbb{H}I≅H.
Now, I think such a category which is not FVecCFVec_{\mathbb{C}}FVecC​ would be the finite-dimensional C\mathbb{C}C-vector bundles over a fixed smooth manifold maybe?

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Now, I think such a category which is not FVecCFVec_{\mathbb{C}}FVecC​ would be the finite-dimensional C\mathbb{C}C-vector bundles over a fixed smooth manifold maybe?

Not every vector bundle is a biproduct of copies of the unit object (the trivial line bundle), but maybe the category of trivial finite-dimensional complex vector bundles will have all the properties you seek.
Ok, nice. That's good for me if such categories are barely more than FVecCFVec_{\mathbb{C}}FVecC​.

In such a category, for every objects A,BA,BA,B, if n≥1n \ge 1n≥1 is the integer such that A≅I⊕nA \cong I^{\oplus n}A≅I⊕n, you can look at C[A⊗p,B]≅C[(I⊕n)⊗p,B]\mathcal{C}[A^{\otimes p},B] \cong \mathcal{C}[(I^{\oplus n})^{\otimes p},B]C[A⊗p,B]≅C[(I⊕n)⊗p,B]

You have an action of Sp\mathfrak{S}_{p}Sp​ on this finite-dimensional C\mathbb{C}C-vector space by composing on the left by the symmetry σI⊕n:(I⊕n)⊗p→(I⊕n)⊗p\sigma_{I^{\oplus n}}:(I^{\oplus n})^{\otimes p} \rightarrow (I^{\oplus n})^{\otimes p}σI⊕n​:(I⊕n)⊗p→(I⊕n)⊗p associated to σ∈Sp\sigma \in \mathfrak{S}_{p}σ∈Sp​
ie. σ.f:=σI⊕n;f\sigma.f := \sigma_{I^{\oplus n}};fσ.f:=σI⊕n​;f
You also have an action of the group of isomorphisms I⊕n→I⊕nI^{\oplus n} \rightarrow I^{\oplus n}I⊕n→I⊕n on this hom-set I think
If ρ:I⊕n→I⊕n\rho:I^{\oplus n} \rightarrow I^{\oplus n}ρ:I⊕n→I⊕n is an isomorphism
You can put ρ.f:=ρ⊗p;f\rho.f := \rho^{\otimes p};fρ.f:=ρ⊗p;f

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

... symmetric monoidal C\mathbb{C}C-linear categories with biproducts such that the monoidal unit III generates the objects ie. every object is isomorphic to I⊕nI^{\oplus n}I⊕n for some n≥1n \ge 1n≥1 ?

By the way, the category of finitely generated free modules over any commutative algebra A over C\mathbb{C}C is a symmetric monoidal category of this sort. And the category of trivial complex vector bundles over a space is an example of this, where we take A to be the algebra of functions on this space.
You may even be able to classify categories of this sort.

John Baez said:

You may even be able to classify categories of this sort.

How would you want to do that?
I mean, do you have some idea?

Well, I think I almost listed them all: remember that End(I) is a commutative algebra over C\mathbb{C}C, and that algebra is A when our category was the category if f.g. free A-modules.

So, it seems likely that the algebra End(I) determines the category up to equivalence, for the sort of category we're discussing.
The only flexibility I see is that there can be various choices of symmetry (and associator, maybe).

So maybe every such category is equivalent (maybe with a symmetric monoidal equivalence that preserves biproducts and also linear combination of morphisms) to the category of finitely generated free modules over End(I)End(I)End(I)
Yes, I now think that's true - except you mean finitely genererated free modules. There are usually lots of other f.g. modules

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

So a question I'm interested about now is: can we generalize Schur-Weyl duality to symmetric monoidal C\mathbb{C}C-linear categories with biproducts such that the monoidal unit III generates the objects ie. every object is isomorphic to I⊕nI^{\oplus n}I⊕n for some n≥1n \ge 1n≥1 ?

It is not quite correct, because here you could have I=HI=\mathbb{H}I=H for instance.

Interesting, but I am afraid that your intended setting does not include the known cases of Howe duality. Notice also that we have also an analogue of Schur-Weyl where you replace complex GLnGL_nGLn​ by finite GLnGL_nGLn​ and Cn\mathbb C^nCn by L2(Fqn)L^2(\mathbb F_q^n)L2(Fqn​) (n=pn=pn=p, in your notations)This is sometimes called Juyumaya duality, after Jesus Juyumaya (which is not a cousin of Azumaya, but a former Ph D student of mine, of Aymara ascent). Check https://arxiv.org/pdf/0801.3633.pdf Again, a baby example is finite GL2 GL_2GL2​ and S2\mathfrak S_2S2​ where GL2 GL_2GL2​ acts via the Weil representation in complex function space on the finite plane and the flip in S2\mathfrak S_2S2​ acts as the Fourier - Grassmann transform J, associated to the unique alternating non-degenerate bilinear form on the finite plane (notice that we have J2=IdJ^2 = Id J2=Id). The concrete question is, however, whether you can find other examples of "dual groups" as spin-offs of your categorical approach.
